Demonstratives are derived from three different stems: əm-, tə-, ta-. Semanti-
cally, these can be divided into two sets. One group of demonstratives expresses
direct pointing to something (proximal deixis), while the other group has dis-
tant deixis meaning.
   Based on examples in the corpus and interviews with consultants, it seems
that the choice of demonstratives is ‘speaker-oriented’, thus the deictic center is
based on the speaker. There are two kinds of deictic demonstratives, those indi-
cating ‘near the speaker, here’ (əm-) and those indicating ‘at a distance, there’
(tə- and ta-).
   The demonstrative adverbs are included as a subset of demonstratives. They
take the special spatial case marker, which occurs only with adverbs and post-
positions (see Sections 5 and 6 below)—and these also show the same distri-
bution as pronouns.
   The proximate locational demonstrative adverb, əmnɨ ‘here’, designates the
place near the speaker, while the distantial demonstrative adverb, tamnu
‘there’, refer to the places that are out of reach of the speaker. These adverbs

6.3.2.4      Inchoative and Resultative Suffixes
Nganasan also has perfectivizing suffixes, which express a normally inchoative,
resultative or temporal meaning. One of the most frequently used derivational
suffixes is the inchoative suffix -LƏ (-lə, -lʲi) with the meaning ‘begin to S’, e.g.
hiďisʲi ‘laugh’ > hisʲi-lə-sʲi ‘begin to laugh’; ďaŋhɨďi ‘shine’ > ďaŋhɨ-lə-sɨ ‘begin
to shine’; ďorəďa ‘cry’ > ďorə-lə-sa ‘begin to cry’. This suffix can also express
semelfactivity, i.e. to indicate that the action happened only once. The stem of
such verbs is always a durative verb referring to a lengthy action, e.g. ďorəďa
‘cry’ > ďorə-lə-sa ‘cry out’; səŋü-r-sa ‘look’ cf. səŋü-lə-sa ‘catch sight of’; hiďisʲi
‘laugh’ > hisʲi-lə-sʲi ‘burst out laughing’. In contrast to Nenets (cf. Nikolaeva 2014:
46), the derivative in Nganasan does not belong to the reflexive inflectional
class, the verb can be conjugated by subjective or objective conjugation as well.
   The inchoative-resultative suffix-Ɂkə is a very frequent and productive deri-
vational suffix. It appears on the S1 stem of the verb. The derivative is always a
perfective verb (S1: V+-Ɂkə → VPerf). The meaning of the derived word is ‘begin
to do something and probably finish doing it as well’; ďarəðɨ-sɨ ‘be ill’: ďarəðɨ-

Adverbs can be formed from adjectives or nouns with several derivational suf-
fixes or certain case suffixes, for example with the genitive plural suffixes -Ɂ
(ńaagəǝ: ńaagəiɁ ‘good’ [adv]) and with the prolative suffixes -mənu (ərəkərə:
ərəkərə-mənu ‘beautifully’). Both suffixes form adverbs of manner. (For the case
suffixes, see Section 3, Chapter 4).
   The caritive suffix -KA2lʲi creates adverbs of manner or circumstance from
nouns, e.g. ŋənduj ‘boat’: ŋəndujkalʲi ‘without a boat’; tuj ‘fire’: tuj-kalʲi ‘without
fire’; tala ‘happiness’: tala-kaľi ‘unhappily’. Another privative denominal suf-

with the word ičuə, which is the present participle form of the copula (isʲa), e.g.

           ChNS_080214_Hibula_flkd.0307       Clitic-like MorphemesThere are some morphemes in Nganasan whose morphological status is not
determined with certainty. Based on the way they are used, they form an inter-
mediate category between derivational suffixes and clitics. They are character-
ized by not behaving consistently: their position can depend on the speaker or
the part of speech of the word as well. Practically all of them can co-occur with
verbal and nominal stems, but not with the same frequency: some morphemes
occur more frequently with nominal stems. But their position in relation to
each other is set, although they do not occur together very often. The following
morphemes belong to this group: -Küə, -KüCmü, -ŋUTU, -ŋA2lə, -Kəlʲičə, -btA2,
-Cčǝ and -uɁ. In the discussion below, I will refer to these morphemes as “clitic-
like morphemes”.

4.3      Coda
The coda is either empty (unfilled) or simple, there are no complex codas
attested, thus consonant clusters in codas are not permitted. There are two
types of empty codas. Some empty codas are truly unfilled, while other codas
are empty because they have an empty slot (where an empty slot does not equal
an empty coda, for empty slot see Section 4.4 below).
   Consonant clusters appear intervocalically, these are coda–onset sequences,
as in ďeb.tu ‘goose’. Both empty and simple codas can be found word-internally
and word-finally. However, in a word-final simple coda only /j/, /m/, /ŋ/, /r/
and /Ɂ/ are present. (For more details, see in Table 2.4 in Section 1.2 above.) In
word-internal codas except for the glottal stop /Ɂ/ and /b/, all obstruents are
prohibited.

4.4       Empty Slot
The empty slot is empty because the consonant in the coda position is deleted
as the results of a synchronic phonological process such as gradation or conso-
nant deletion (for example, degemination), or the consonant in the coda has
developed through historical change. But a trace of these consonants remains,
in the form of an empty slot. A syllable ending in an empty slot behaves like
a syllable with a coda. However, an empty slot can never be filled, so a coda
ending in an empty slot cannot be called an empty coda. An empty slot char-
acteristically behaves as if the coda were filled with a consonant (n, k, t, or s),
thus, it plays a role in blocking some phonological processes, such as consonant
gradation, or in triggering others, such as consonant deletion (see Sections 7.1
and 7.6 below).
   Former descriptions of Nganasan phonology (Helimski 1994a and 1998, Vár-
nai 2002 and 2010, Wagner-Nagy 2009) do not refer to empty slots, but they
postulate a zero- or quasi-consonant, written as /C/. The differences between
the two models is that the former descriptions postulate a null or empty con-
sonant that will either be realized or not. The model presented in this work
is based on the syllable structure and not on the phoneme. The empty slot
(marked with C) is present in all positions, as the examples in (13) show.

7.6.1       Deletion of the Stem-Final Consonant
As mentioned in Section 1.2, the distribution of consonants at the end of words
is restricted; only /Ɂ/, /m/, /ŋ/, /r/ and /j/ occur in this position. As described
in Section 1, there are no long consonants in Nganasan. If a sequence of two
identical consonants is created during suffixation, they are always degeminated
or otherwise eliminated. However, the consonant deleted during degemina-
tion keeps its position in the syllable as an empty slot (see Section 4.4 above).
Evidence for this is reflected by the fact that consonants affected by Syllabic
Gradation continue to be in the weak grade even though its surface form is

Suffixes beginning with a glottal stop always connect to the stem with a linking
vowel. When connecting to stems with consonants, suffixes beginning with -r
alternate with -l. The stem-final -r is always preserved as in malʲir+Rə → malʲirlə
‘your nomad camp’. This process is described in Section 7.7 below.

stem-final /ŋ/ disappears before suffixes that begin with a liquid or nasal, while
before suffixes beginning with a stop it alternates with /n/ (for more on nasal
assimilation, see Section 7.3.2). The stem final -j and -r do not take part in
this process, as the examples in (44) below demonstrate they are always pre-
served. It ought to be noted that the deleted consonants (-Ɂ, -ŋ and -m) become
empty segments. As the examples show, the suffix-initial trill turns into a liquid

phonetics and phonology                                                          87   Deleted segments block or even trigger gradation. This occurs, for example,
in the word tugɨCmǝ ‘my cloth’. The consonant /g/ in all forms is in syllabic
weak grade, because the empty segment /C/ closes the syllable. Furthermore,
the suffix-initial -t in 3sgposs is in strong grade, although it is in the onset of
an odd numbered syllable and, as such, should be of rhythmic weak grade, if
the ⟨C⟩ did not block this process. (For more on gradation, see Section 7.1; on
empty slot, see Section 4.4.)
   Note that the stem final -j palatalizes the first consonant of the suffixes and
often coalesces with it. This latter process is not obligatory, but is speaker spe-
cific. Thus a /jt/ sequence appears as ⟨jč⟩ or even as ⟨č⟩ (cf. Section 7.4.1).
   In the case of several verbal stems, in some forms the stem ends in a conso-
nant (e.g. aor.3sg) and in others it ends in a vowel (e.g. inf). This phenomenon
can be explained, if we hypothesize an empty slot at the end of the stem. The
corresponding strong grade consonants are /t/, /s/ and rarely /k/, which are
however deleted before the infinitive ending. These stems behave as if the stem
ended in a consonant: the stem-internal consonants are in weak grade due to
SG in closed syllable, as in noguC.sa ‘to approach’. Furthermore, the suffix-initial
consonant is in its strong grade, because the empty segment blocks RG, as in
bəu-sa ‘cross’ (instead of *bəu-ďa). If there were not an empty segment, rhyth-
mic weak grade would surface at the beginning of an odd numbered syllable
or after a VV sequence. In the aorist forms, the stem-final consonants stay in a
closed syllable, for this reason the Syllabic Gradation operates on them. Exam-
ples are given in (45).

              JSM_090809_Life_nar.0422.3     Biaspectual Verbs
Biaspectual verbs are underived verb stems that can be followed by either of
the two aorist suffixes. One of these suffixes implies that the verb in the aorist
tense has present meaning, while in the other case, the meaning is past, as in
hu͡aŋku-ďa ‘be drunk’: hu͡aŋka-Ɂa-m ‘I have got drunk.’ or hu͡aŋku-tu-m ‘I am
drunk.’
3       Conjugations TypesSimilar to other Northern Samoyedic languages (Nenets and Enets), there are
three conjugation types: subjective, objective and reflexive-medial. Every con-
jugation type has its own set of inflectional endings. Personal suffixes express
the number of the object and so, there are three paradigms in the objective
conjugation, referring to 1) one object 2) two objects 3) more than two objects.
Verbal personal suffixes attach to a verbal stem followed by a tense or mood
marker. The S1 form of this relative stem (absolute stem + tense/mood marker)
is followed by the personal suffix.
